reviewText: Good movie about some French Foreign Legionnaires' experiences during the Algerian war for independence from France back in the 1950s and 1960s.
Not very accurate and don favour the Legionnaires.

Good take on the Algerian fight for independence circa 1960. Realistically portrayed, solid acting from multiple perspectives recommended for anyone interested in the politics and emotional turmoil of colonial North Africa. A definite recommendation for students in my class studying terrorism who have first developed the background to better appreciate the film. I bounced this four to four and one-half star flick (IMO) up to 5-stars to generate more interest in the film for those who will understand it. I found the film actually got better when watching it a second and third time. Don't expect the typical Hollywood-style action flick and brush up on your French and you might like it as well. Of course you can also read the English subtitles and let the language barrier fade into the background after the first 15 to 20 minutes.

If you 'get it,' you may start to understand much of the basis of the current conflicts and terrorist activity in North Africa and the Middle East. If you don't 'get it,' well, sorry, but there's no quick way to provide the necessary background for understanding the film or the current rise in terrorist activity worldwide.
Based on the excellent book "Legionnaire" by Englishman Simon Murray, this is a so-so adaptation of story. This low budget movie would've been helped by having a cast of more than 2 dozen.
A well made, no frills film. Not beau geste, but down to earth, and he gets the girl in the end. "Vive la Legion!"
Decent show,  gives a good retelling of what was happening to the French Empire after WW2

A film that shows multiple points of view (soldiers, civilians, partisans) from those caught in war. Somehow the sadistic training instills toughness in the recruits. Many with military experience have "been there, done that"  (to a much lesser degree) so it might work even if this film didn't show much in the way of letting these guys grow into competence.  The problem with the film - even if Murray provides interesting insights and relationships- are the couple of casual horror incidents by Legionnaires, whose actions are not even required as part of the brutality of war. Even with these super-tough guys, the officer's would have to realize their controlled beast was off its leash, if they pulled the soup stunt and the troops just laughed. But for the few scenes, it was interesting to watch what these guys got themselves into. BTW: This movie was originally released in 2002 as "Deserter."
Great movie in the classical sense

Interesting film. Cast could have done better. Direction Ok. But screenplay made the French look like the good guys.
Story could have been deeper about conflict.

To be honest. I Love #TomHardy and I'll watch him in anything. First, #LegionofHonor and #Deserter are the same movie so no need to buy twice or rent. The movie wasn't that good.

Don't be fooled like me into buying the exact same film twice whether it is called "Deserter" or "Legion of Honor"

Tom Hardy is a key but ancillary character.  A Frenchman who joins the French Foreign Legion with two buddies from Spain.

It's 1960 so they are sent to Algeria for their mandatory minimum service of 5 years to fight France's ill fated attempt to keep its colony in Algeria.  They ostensibly fight the Algerian resistance, but they also fight the French colonists who don't want to leave Algeria as well as the regular French army under DeGsulle which wants to cut its losses, declare victory, and go home to France

The film centers on an English volunteer who wrote the book upon which the movie is based.

Their indoctrination/boot camp is hell, but this group of unlikely misfits bonds into a unit.  It quickly becomes obvious to the Brit that the French do not belong in Algeria after he tries to befriend Algerians and French colonists, the Pied noir or black feet
Decent movie about the French trying to hold on to their colony.

This is a serious movie which was made to score some serious points. It seems to me that many of the negative reviewers did not watch the movie through to the end. Or else they did not watch it at all.

Also called "Deserter."  2002 Movie.  Well done film about the French Foreign legion complete with a much more realistic look at life in the Legion versus the glamorized versions.  Brutal indoctrination, shallow friends bonded by adversity versus ideals.  Timed during the Algerian fight for independence and all of the turmoil it entails, even for the Legion.  In the end I was surprised by this reasonably accurate version of Legion life and a most interesting ending......The movie was well done!

An awful adaptation of Simon Murray's book "Legionnaire". I can't believe that Murray had anything to do with this tripe, it completely went the opposite direction of the book. Simon Murray exposed the brutal side of the Legion in the book but he was proud to have served in the Legion & left as an honored Legionnaire. The movie made it seem like he couldn't wait to get out & hated every second he was in the force. The movie also suffered from weak characters, poor script & so-so battle scenes. Do yourself a favor & pass on this one.
